342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block 1
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"-- A table to store the position of trucks over time.
CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE truck_locations
(
    x float,
    y float,
    TRACKID varchar(64),
    DEPOT_ID integer,
    sids integer,
    TIMESTAMP timestamp,
    shard_key(TRACKID)
);

-- Load data
LOAD DATA INTO truck_locations
FROM FILE PATH ''
FORMAT JSON
WITH OPTIONS (
    DATA SOURCE = 'truck_locations_source',
    SUBSCRIBE = TRUE,
    TYPE_INFERENCE_MODE = 'speed',
    ERROR_HANDLING = 'permissive',
    kafka_subscription_cancel_after = 120 -- cancels the stream after 120 minutes
);

-- Create a view to represent the last 2 hours of data
CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW recent_locations
REFRESH EVERY 5 SECONDS AS 
SELECT * 
FROM truck_locations 
WHERE TIMEBOUNDARYDIFF('HOUR', TIMESTAMP, NOW()) < 2"

342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE dc_fences 
(
    fence_id int,
    wkt geometry,
    fence_label varchar(32)
);"

342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"TABLE WITH FENCES","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The table below is used to store a set of fences that outline major landmarks in Washington DC."}]}]

342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"STREAM OF GPS COORDINATES OF 7 TRUCKS IN DC","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The block of code below creates a table for recording the position of trucks in and around DC and connects to a kafka data source that is streaming GPS coordinates from these trucks."}]}]

342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"LOAD DATA INTO dc_fences
FROM FILE PATHS 'landmark_fences.csv'
FORMAT TEXT 
WITH OPTIONS (
    DATA SOURCE = 'examples_data'
);"

342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"-- Create the data source. Each kafka topic is created as a separate data source.
LOAD DATA INTO taxi_trips
FORMAT JSON
WITH OPTIONS (
    DATA SOURCE = 'ny_taxi_stream',
    SUBSCRIBE = 'TRUE',
    TYPE_INFERENCE_MODE = 'speed',
    ERROR_HANDLING = 'permissive',
    kafka_subscription_cancel_after = 120 -- cancels the stream after 120 minutes  
);"

342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"NY TAXI","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A stream of NY taxi trips. This is for the binning sheet."}]}]

342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
Block
342ca9e0-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"CREATE THE DATA SOURCES","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We will be using three different data sources for this example. Two Kafka topics and one small file loaded from AWS S3. Our first task is to register all of these data sources so that we can connect to them."}]}]

34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"COMPUTE ATTRIBUTES"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's calculate the areas of the fences around landmarks in Washington DC using ST_AREA()."}]}]

34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"IDENTIFY SPATIAL RELATIONSHIPS","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's see if there are any fences that overlap using the ST_INTERSECTS function."}]}]

34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"SELECT 
    a.fence_id, 
    a.fence_label,
    b.fence_label as overlap,
    a.wkt
FROM dc_fences AS a, dc_fences AS b
WHERE ST_INTERSECTS(a.wkt, b.wkt) = 1 AND a.fence_label != b.fence_label"

34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"CONSTRUCT GEOMETRIES","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's dissolve all the fences to create a single geometry. Notice how the boundaries between the overlapping fences (bottom left) have been dissolved in the map below. "}]}]

34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: "CREATE OR REPLACE TEMP TABLE dc_dissolved AS \nSELECT ST_DISSOLVE(wkt) as wkt\nFROM dc_fences "

34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This section is a primer on geospatial analytics. Feel free to skip it if you have already worked with the ST function library from PostGIS."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"VIDEO PLAYLIST","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The video below is the start of a playlist that introduces geospatial analysis with Kinetica. Go through to it to familiarize yourself with the fundamentals of spatial analytics."}]}]

34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34883760-c84e-11ed-ba25-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"THE ST FUNCTION LIBRARY","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The ST functions library contains a wide range of functions related to spatial geometry, data analysis, and spatial data management. This library can be used to create and manipulate spatial data, perform spatial calculations and queries, generate maps and visualizations, and much more."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kinetica offers more than 150 different ST_ functions. These can be broadly classified into the 3 categories shown below (based on their purpose)."}]}]

34d2fc00-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34d2fc00-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WHAT IS GEOFENCING?","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Geofencing is a location-based service in which a software application uses GPS, RFID, Wi-Fi or cellular data to trigger a pre-programmed action when a mobile device or RFID tag enters or exits a virtual boundary set up around a geographical location. Geofencing can be used for various purposes, such as sending notifications to customers when they enter or leave an area, providing targeted advertising based on location, and tracking employee time and attendance."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"GEOFENCES"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Take a look at the data set up sheet before proceeding. This will give you a good sense for what the query below is accomplishing. We have two tables of data. One is a stream that is recording live locations of different trucks Washington DC, while the second is a list of fences surrounding popular DC landmarks."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The query below identifies when a trucks GPS points falls within a fence. We only consider events that have occured in the last 5 minutes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"WHY IS THE MAP EMPTY?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"First check if you have run the query below. The maps reference the data from the view that is created in that query. If the maps still stay empty it means that there are no geofencing events currently. But one will likely show up within a few minutes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"AUTOMAGICALLY UPDATE WITH A MATERIALIZED VIEW","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The query below uses a materialized view that is set to refresh on change. So the results of this view are updated automatically whenever there is a new truck location added to Kinetica from the Kafka stream. A downstream application that relies on these geofencing events can simply point to this table in Kinetica and rely on our high speed key value lookups to deliver real time event alerts."}]}]

34d2fc00-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34d2fc00-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW fence_events 
REFRESH ON CHANGE AS 
SELECT 
    TRACKID, 
    wkt, 
    x, 
    y, 
    TIMESTAMP, 
    CONCAT(TRACKID, CONCAT(' is at ', fence_label)) as event_text 
FROM recent_locations, dc_fences
WHERE 
    STXY_CONTAINS(wkt, x, y) = 1 AND 
    TIMEBOUNDARYDIFF('MINUTE', TIMESTAMP, NOW()) < 5;

SELECT * FROM fence_events"

34e74750-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block 1
34e74750-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW vehicle_fence_join 
REFRESH ON CHANGE AS
SELECT 
    TRACKID, 
    x,
    y,
    DECIMAL(STXY_DISTANCE(x, y, wkt, 1)) as distance,
    fence_label,
    wkt
FROM recent_locations
INNER JOIN dc_fences 
    ON 
    STXY_DWITHIN(x, y, wkt, 200, 1) = 1;

"

34e74750-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34e74750-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WHAT IS A SPATIAL JOIN?","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Spatial joins combine two different tables using a spatial relationship. They are used to answer questions such as “which areas overlap”, “where do the boundaries occur”, and “what is the area covered by a certain feature”. Spatial joins are typically computationally expensive to perform especially on larger data. But Kinetica can handle this with ease. In fact, not only that it can keep the view maintained in real time as new data streams in. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"bold":true,"text":"A SPATIAL JOIN"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the code below, we use a join to identify records where a truck is within 200 meters of a particular fence. "}]}]

34e74750-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
34e74750-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"MAP SHOWING THE FENCES THAT HAD A RECENT TRUCK LOCATION (MARKED IN BLUE) WITHIN 200 METERS","bold":true}]}]

350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block 1
350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW fence_trucks
REFRESH EVERY 5 SECONDS AS
SELECT *
FROM TABLE
(
    ST_TRACKINTERSECTS
    (
        TRACK_TABLE => INPUT_TABLE
        (
            SELECT * 
            FROM recent_locations
            WHERE TIMEBOUNDARYDIFF('MINUTE', TIMESTAMP, NOW()) < 5
        ),
        TRACK_ID_COLUMN => 'TRACKID',
        TRACK_X_COLUMN => 'x',
        TRACK_Y_COLUMN => 'y',
        TRACK_ORDER_COLUMN => 'TIMESTAMP',
        GEOFENCE_TABLE => INPUT_TABLE(dc_fences),
        GEOFENCE_ID_COLUMN => 'fence_id',
        GEOFENCE_WKT_COLUMN => 'wkt'
    )
);

SELECT * FROM fence_trucks"

350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WHAT ARE TRACKS?","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Tracks are a "},{"text":"native","italic":true},{"text":" geospatial object in Kinetica (just like Points, Shapes and Labels). They represent objects in motion i.e. the path that an object takes over time. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"HOW ARE TRACKS REPRESENTED?","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Tracks use a combination of a track identifier, a timestamp value and X and Y coordinates to represent a path over time. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WHY ARE TRACKS USEFUL?","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Pretty much any object that moves can be represented and studied using tracks. This has a wide range of application in almost all sectors of the economy including supply chain management, ride sharing, IoT devices. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WHATS THE BENEFIT OF STUDYING TRACKS IN KINETICA?","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kinetica come with a set of functions that can be used to compute attributes and to detect events such as geofencing and proximity to other tracks. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Apart from all the performance benefits, Kinetica's native track representation performs a key function, which is "},{"text":"track interpolation","bold":true},{"text":", which allows us to infer events such as geofencing and proximity more accurately."}]}]

350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"-- Compute the length and duration of tracks
CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW truck_summary
REFRESH EVERY 5 SECOND AS
SELECT 
    TRACKID,
    ROUND(ST_TRACKLENGTH(Y, X,TIMESTAMP, 1) / 1000) AS track_length_km, 
    ROUND(ST_TRACKDURATION(MINUTE,TIMESTAMP)) as duration_mins
FROM recent_locations 
GROUP BY TRACKID;


SELECT * FROM truck_summary"

350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"TRACK ATTRIBUTES","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's calculate the length and duration each of the truck tracks. "}]}]

350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"TRACK INTERSECTION","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's identify if any of the trucks have intersected with the DC landmark fences."}]}]

350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"TRACK PROXIMITY","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's detect if two different trucks came within 200 meters of each other within a 1 minute window."}]}]

350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
350619f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"-- Identify tracks that came within 200 meters of each other within a 1 minute window
CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW proximate_trucks 
REFRESH EVERY 1 MINUTE AS 
SELECT * FROM TABLE 
(
    ST_TRACK_DWITHIN
    (
        TRACK_TABLE => INPUT_TABLE(recent_locations),
        TRACK_ID_COLUMN => 'TRACKID',
        TRACK_X_COLUMN =>  'x',
        TRACK_Y_COLUMN =>  'y',
        TRACK_ORDER_COLUMN =>  'TIMESTAMP',
        SEARCH_TABLE => INPUT_TABLE(recent_locations),
        SEARCH_ID_COLUMN =>  'TRACKID',
        SEARCH_X_COLUMN =>  'x',
        SEARCH_Y_COLUMN =>  'y',
        SEARCH_ORDER_COLUMN =>  'TIMESTAMP',
            SEARCH_XY_DISTANCE => '200',
            SPATIAL_SOLUTION_TYPE => 1,
            SEARCH_TIME_DISTANCE => '1m'
    )
)
WHERE TRACK_TABLE_TRACKID <> SEARCH_TABLE_TRACKID;

SELECT * FROM proximate_trucks;"

354593f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
354593f0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"DEDICATED GRAPH LIBRARY","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kinetica offers an extensive library of Graph functions that can be used to create, query, solve and match graphs using tons of prebuilt solvers and identifier combinations. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"GRAPH + GEO  👨‍❤️‍💋‍👨","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Routing is a key area of spatial analytics. Kinetica's can represent road networks as graphs against which we can issue powerful pre-built solvers and match algorithms. This makes it really easy to solve spatial problems with a routing flavor. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And what's more, Graphs in Kinetica are fully compatible with a relational data model, so you can integrate graph analytics with your existing analytical data pipelines without any friction."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"TRY THE SHORTEST PATH WORKBOOK","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We have a separate workbook that goes into the basics of using graphs in Kinetica. Try that out next!"}]}]

354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"-- Calculate the h3 index for each pickup and dropoff point
CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW nytaxi_h3_index
REFRESH EVERY 5 SECONDS AS 
SELECT 
    pickup_latitude,
    pickup_longitude,
    STXY_H3(pickup_longitude, pickup_latitude, 9) AS h3_index_pickup,
    STXY_H3(dropoff_longitude, dropoff_latitude, 9) AS h3_index_dropff
FROM taxi_trips;
"

354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"BIN TAXI TRIPS IN NY TO FIND HOTSPOTS","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Spatial binning is a technique used in data analysis to group geographically-referenced data into user-defined bins or areas. The technique is used to reduce the resolution of a dataset, making it easier to visualize and analyze large datasets. This can be done by dividing the area into equal-sized rectangular grids, circles, polygons, or hexagons. The resulting bins are then used for statistical analysis such as calculating the frequency of events or measuring average values."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kinetica offers two ways to generate grids - ST_HEXGRID or using H3 geohashing functions (based on Uber). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's use the latter to visualize hotspots for taxi pickups in New York. The steps are as follows."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Use STXY_H3() to generate the H3 index, which is a number that points to a specific h3 grid that contains a particular x and y point. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. Use ST_GEOMFROMH3() to generate the corresponding geom for each index we generated in the previous step."}]}]

354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"-- Create the grid geom and aggregate pickups within each
CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW nytaxi_binned
REFRESH ON CHANGE AS 
SELECT 
    h3_index_pickup,
    ST_GEOMFROMH3(h3_index_pickup) AS h3_cell,
    COUNT(*) AS total_pickups
FROM nytaxi_h3_index 
GROUP BY h3_index_pickup"

354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The map below shows the total pickups aggregated within each bin in NY. Both the queries above are based on a stream of taxi rides coming from Kafka, and they are set to refresh with new data. This means that map below (which is set to refresh every few seconds) will also update to show the real time information on pickups across NYC."}]}]

354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
354e94a0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"TASKS FOR YOU TO EXPLORE","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Clone this workbook to create an editable version of this example and try these out on your own."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Mirror the same for dropoffs."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. Who pays more on average? Compare average taxi fares across different parts of NY"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"3. Who tips more? Compare tipping across different parts of NY"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"4. Who shares rides more? Compare average passenger counts across different parts of NY"}]}]

357619d0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block 1
357619d0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE fence_filter AS
SELECT wkt
FROM dc_fences 
WHERE ST_AREA(wkt, 1) > 500000"

357619d0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
357619d0-c84e-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"SPATIAL FILTERING","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A spatial filter is used to identify a subset of records from a table that meet some "},{"text":"criteria","italic":true},{"text":" based on a specific spatial query."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"CRITERIA","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Find fences that have a truck within 200 meters from them."}]}]

9c3e61b0-c856-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block 1
9c3e61b0-c856-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content:
"CREATE OR REPLACE MATERIALIZED VIEW alert_text
REFRESH ON CHANGE AS 
SELECT 
    TRACKID,
    event_text
FROM fence_events;

-- CREATE A STREAM 
CREATE STREAM fence_alerts ON 
alert_text
REFRESH ON CHANGE 
WITH OPTIONS 
(
    DESTINATION = 'https://eolylaanwtts64t.m.pipedream.net' 
)"

9c3e61b0-c856-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.name: Block
9c3e61b0-c856-11ed-ba26-8b829b95b0e1.content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"EVENT STREAMING","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Let's say we want to trigger an event alert anytime there is a geofence event we saw in the previous worksheet. We can does using a stream. A stream can send records from Kinetica into other data sinks like Kafka or a simple webhook. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"SEE EVENTS BEING STREAMED IN REAL TIME","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For this illustration, we will use the latter to send records to a pipedream webhook and then hook that up to the following google spreadsheet: https://bit.ly/3JxJRO9"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Copy the link above and paste in your browsers address bar to see geofence events being detected in real time by Kinetica."}]}]
